verses.text: Now Pashhur the son of Immer, the priest who was chief officer in the house of the Lord, heard Jeremiah prophesying these things.
verses.comment: Pashhur was a high-ranking priest responsible for order in the temple. His reaction demonstrates the growing opposition to Jeremiah's prophetic message.

verses.text: Then Pashhur struck Jeremiah the prophet and put him in the stocks that were at the Upper Benjamin Gate of the house of the Lord.
verses.comment: Imprisoning Jeremiah foreshadows the persecution of those who speak God’s truth. The stocks were instruments of public humiliation. The link to Acts 4:3 highlights the continuity of suffering among God's prophets.

verses.text: On the next day, when Pashhur released Jeremiah from the stocks, Jeremiah said to him, 'The Lord does not call you Pashhur, but Terror on Every Side.'
verses.comment: Jeremiah renames Pashhur symbolically, revealing God's judgment. 'Terror on Every Side' is a phrase recurrent in Jeremiah and Psalms, indicating divine retribution.

verses.text: For thus says the Lord: 'Behold, I will make you a terror to yourself and to all your friends, and they shall fall by the sword of their enemies while you look on. And I will give all Judah into the hand of the king of Babylon, who will take them captive to Babylon and kill them with the sword.'
verses.comment: Jeremiah’s prophecy was fulfilled in the Babylonian exile. The warning pertains to both spiritual and physical consequences, a pattern seen throughout salvation history.

verses.text: 'And I will give all the wealth of this city, all its gains, all its prized possessions, and all the treasures of the kings of Judah, into the hand of their enemies, who will plunder them, seize them, and carry them to Babylon.'
verses.comment: Material and spiritual loss is a consequence of turning away from God. This prophecy echoes previous warnings given to Israel regarding faithfulness and ransom (Isaiah 39:6).

verses.text: 'And you, Pashhur, and all who dwell in your house, shall go into captivity. You shall go to Babylon, and there you shall die, and there you shall be buried, you and all your friends, to whom you have prophesied falsely.'
verses.comment: False prophecy leads to destruction. Jeremiah’s warnings parallel the consequences of spiritual error, emphasizing the importance of truth in faith and leadership.

verses.text: O Lord, you have deceived me, and I was deceived; you are stronger than I, and you have prevailed. I have become a laughingstock all day; everyone mocks me.
verses.comment: Jeremiah shares his distress with God, echoing themes of suffering found in the Psalms and in the experiences of Christ. This vulnerability points to the honesty of relationship with God.

verses.text: For whenever I speak, I cry out, I shout, 'Violence and destruction!' Because the word of the Lord has become for me a reproach and derision all day long.
verses.comment: Prophets often face rejection. Jeremiah’s perseverance mirrors the steadfastness seen in Christ and the apostles when proclaiming unpopular truth.

verses.text: If I say, 'I will not mention him or speak anymore in his name,' then there is in my heart as it were a burning fire shut up in my bones, and I am weary of holding it in, and I cannot.
verses.comment: The compelling nature of God's word is a theme that echoes throughout scripture. This 'fire' points to the active grace sustaining prophets and prefigures the indwelling Spirit in Acts.

verses.text: For I have heard many whispering, 'Terror on every side! Report him, let us report him!' All my close friends are watching for me to stumble, saying, 'Perhaps he will be deceived, and then we can prevail against him and take our revenge on him.'
verses.comment: This betrayal by friends is reminiscent of the experiences of David and foreshadows Christ's betrayal. The phrase 'Terror on every side' recurs as a motif of judgment and isolation.

verses.text: But the Lord is with me as a mighty warrior; therefore my persecutors shall stumble, and they shall not prevail. They will be greatly shamed, for they will not succeed. Their eternal dishonor will never be forgotten.
verses.comment: Jeremiah's confidence in divine protection attests to faith in God’s ultimate justice. This motif encourages perseverance in opposing evil and trusting in God's supremacy.

verses.text: O Lord of hosts, you test the righteous; you see the heart and the mind. Let me see your vengeance on them, for to you I have committed my cause.
verses.comment: God is portrayed as the perfect judge, knowing inner motives. This verse subtly affirms the importance of committing oneself fully to God’s providence and judgment.

verses.text: Sing to the Lord; praise the Lord! For he has delivered the life of the needy from the hand of evildoers.
verses.comment: Despite suffering, Jeremiah responds in worship and declares God’s ability to save. This echoes Davidic praise and encourages adoration even in trial.

verses.text: Cursed be the day on which I was born! The day when my mother bore me, let it not be blessed!
verses.comment: Jeremiah's lamentation echoes Job’s distress, acknowledging deep suffering. The spiritual interpretation points to redemptive suffering and the human experience of despair turned to hope.

verses.text: Cursed be the man who brought the news to my father, saying, 'A son is born to you,' making him very glad.
verses.comment: The distress is so great that even the announcement of Jeremiah’s birth is regretted. This reflects the prophet’s burden and the cost of carrying divine truth.

verses.text: Let that man be like the cities that the Lord overthrew and did not relent; let him hear a cry in the morning and an alarm at noon,
verses.comment: Reference to divine judgment as in Sodom and Gomorrah, symbolizing total destruction. It warns of spiritual consequences for opposing God's mission.

verses.text: because he did not kill me in the womb; so my mother would have been my grave, and her womb forever great.
verses.comment: Jeremiah’s agony reflects a desire to escape suffering, yet he persists. References to the sanctity of life in the womb invite reflection on God’s purpose in creation.

verses.text: Why did I come out from the womb to see trouble and sorrow, and that my days should end in shame?
verses.comment: Jeremiah’s lament concludes with an existential question about suffering. This nonetheless foreshadows Christ’s own passion and recalls how redemptive suffering can bring salvation to many.
